Police often stop street artists, and some of them must pay fines. City councils say that cleaning graffiti from buildings, buses, and trains costs a lot of money.

Some people say writing down your dreams helps you have lucid dreams. A lucid dream is when you know you are dreaming. You can decide what happens. You can turn a scary dream into a safe one. Or you can direct the story like a film director. Instead of finding the meaning of your dreams, create them. You may want some dreams that let your subconscious share its thoughts. You can also create new ones.

Pi is 16 years old. A new government is chosen. Pi’s parents do not support this government. They are worried about the future, so they decide to close the zoo. They also decide to move to Canada. Some animals are sold to zoos in North America. Pi’s family travels by ship to Canada with the animals. On the way, a big storm happens. The ship sinks. Pi’s family and the sailors drown. Pi survives. He is in a lifeboat with a hyena, a zebra, an orang‑utan, and a big tiger.

The Hunger Games is a very popular book for teens. It was written by an American author named Suzanne Collins. The book was published in 2008. Since then, it has been translated into 26 languages. It has sold millions of copies all over the world. It was the first book for young readers that sold more than a million e‑books. The book was turned into a big Hollywood movie. The movie is also very successful. In its first weekend, the movie earned 152.5 million dollars in North America.

A big influence on *The Hunger Games* is Suzanne Collins’ love of Greek mythology. When she was a child, she liked the story of Theseus and the Minotaur. In that story, the city of Athens is ruled by the island of Crete. The Athenians rebel, and the king of Crete, Minos, punishes them. He forces the Athenians to send seven boys and seven girls to Crete every year. The children are put into a maze and are eaten by a monster called the Minotaur. But one of the children, Theseus, fights the monster and kills it. Collins sees Katniss Everdeen as a modern Theseus.

In the past, many bridges were made of wood. Wooden bridges could catch fire easily. This was especially true for old train bridges. Sparks from the steel wheels and tracks could set a wooden bridge on fire, and the bridge could then burn down.

News stories often make us think the world is very violent. But there is some good news. From the end of World War II to 1990, 30 wars killed more than 100,000 people. Today there are still civil wars, but most countries live together more peacefully. Terrorism has increased in recent years. Since World War II, wars have killed more civilians than soldiers. For civilians, the numbers are not all bad. Violent crime kills nine times more people than political conflict, because it happens more often. The global murder rate went down a little. It was 8 per 100,000 people in 2000 and about 5.3 in 2015.

Suzanne Collines has always found news about wars upsetting. When she was a child, her father was a pilot in the U.S. Air Force and he fought in Vietnam. Her mother tried to protect her by not telling her what was happening in the war, but Suzanne still saw news programmes about the war and knew her dad was there. It was a very frightening experience for her.

The rover checks the air around it. In 2014 it found a basic organic molecule and methane. Methane is a main part of natural gas. Methane does not last long. It only survives a few hundred years. Because of this, something on Mars must keep making more methane. NASA says Mars releases thousands of tons of methane at a time. The level of methane rises and falls with the seasons, almost as if the planet is breathing.

A new trend is growing against shopping culture. It is called the ‘buy nothing’ trend. The idea started in Canada in the early 1990s. It then spread to the United States. When it reached the US, many people began to reject the big sales of Black Friday and Cyber Monday. On Buy Nothing Day, people organize marches and sometimes cut their credit cards. This day is part of the Thanksgiving weekend. Throughout the year, Buy Nothing groups organize exchanges and repairs of items they already own.

It was a very interesting talk. The speaker made a good point about several things. For example, parents influence their children. How can we expect teenagers to stop texting while doing homework if they see their parents posting on social media while cooking dinner or waiting at a red light? The speaker also said that people want to be in many places at once. So they switch between real life and online chats. I see this all the time with my teenage daughter and her friends. They plan to meet, and then sit together quietly while each one talks on their phone.

Gary Collins is a policeman who was off duty. He was watching the London riots on TV. He saw many familiar faces. He decided to leave his holiday early to help identify them. For six months he looked at the CCTV footage. He identified 190 people, many just by their eyes. His work was very important for the investigation. Even though there were 200,000 hours of footage, a computer program could only find one person.

Gabriela was frustrated for many weeks.  
She sent an email to her manager in Sweden.  
In the email she said she had problems with her team.  
The manager replied.  
He asked if she thought the team was still performing well.  
He also asked what could help her work better with her team members.  
Gabriela felt the manager was vague.  
She did not feel he was handling the situation well.

Wasfia has spent her life helping human rights.  
She has seen many projects that teach women and girls in her country.  
But many of those projects stop and the women have nothing left.  
Wasfia thought Bangladesh must stand up for itself.  
She mixed two of her interests: climbing mountains and human rights.  
She wants to change how people view women in her country.  
She began climbing when she worked on projects in Tibet and Nepal.  
In Bangladesh, a flat country, most people have never seen a mountain.  
Her campaign is working. People in her country and the world are paying attention.

Wild animals often come into cities to find food. In Cape Town, South Africa, baboons have started to visit homes on the city edge. They open rubbish bins and eat fruit from gardens and orchards. Some bold baboons even enter houses and take food from cupboards and fridges. Baboons can be aggressive and have attacked many pet animals. Because of this, many city residents do not welcome them.

The Hunger Games happens in the future, after North America was destroyed. The country is called Panem. It has twelve poor districts. The rich Capitol controls them. The Capitol has all the power. Every district makes something for the Capitol. District 12, where the story starts, makes coal. There used to be a thirteenth district. It fought against the Capitol, but the Capitol destroyed it.

Many people in Berlin, Germany said that shooting pigs was cruel. Hunters and animal lovers argued strongly about this. Because of the protests, the city council decided to use a calmer way to control pigs. Instead of shooting them, the council built fences and banned people from feeding the pigs. We will see if this plan works. It might be hard because the winters are warmer now, so there are more pigs than before.

Early in her career, Carol Dweck, an expert from Stanford University, gave a group of children aged ten some tasks. The tasks were a little too hard for them. One group liked the task. They said they liked it and thought their skills could get better. Dweck called this a growth mindset (thinking you can get better). These children paid attention to what they could reach later.

The second group felt that their smartness was being judged. They thought they did not succeed. They had a fixed mindset (thinking you cannot get better) and could not think about improving. Some of these children said they might copy later, and others looked for a person who did worse than them to feel better about themselves.

Sam squinted against the bright sun while watching the dust trail the car had left behind on its way up to the Big House. The horses kicked and flicked their tails at flies, ignoring the fact that their owner was visiting for the first time in ten months. Sam waited patiently. Mr. Carter only came out when he had to, and Sam was happy with that. The more Mr. Carter stayed out of Sam’s way, the longer Sam could keep his job. Mr. Carter wiped the sweat from the back of his neck. The damp patches on his shirt looked like shapes on a map. His skin was already turning ruddy under the June sun. He had the indoor tan of a man who made money while other people did the work.

Another idea to keep Earth safe from a dangerous asteroid is to destroy it with a nuclear bomb. This sounds like a movie plot. It was in the 1998 film *Armageddon*. But HAMMER is a real NASA plan. The plan uses rockets that weigh eight tons. The rockets would hit the asteroid and try to change its path. If the asteroid is too close, the rockets would carry nuclear bombs to explode it.
